attributes.name: salmon
attributes.title: salmon
attributes.description:
Spring and summer run salmon from the Columbia River. Also known as the Chinook Salmon, the Columbia River King salmon have played a major role in the livelihood of the Pacific Northwest Chinook Indians as not only a major source of food but also a spiritual and economic resource as well. The Chinook tribe understood that catching these salmon early in their journey was essential in finding the fish at their healthiest. This also meant a maximum oil reserve ensuring the best possible flavor which made the salmon a valuable commodity. Today that practice holds true.


View Larger Map

attributes.name: mustard oil
attributes.title: mustard oil
attributes.description:
grown and pressed in ME.  
Maine Natural Oils are, for Mainers and New Englanders, local products. Local growing of the crop and simple mechanical cold pressing reduces energy inputs such as long-range transportation and the chemicals ordinarily used in commercial commodity oil production. Maine Natural Oils are a hand made product. We are enthusiastic supporters of the local food movement.

View Larger Map

attributes.name: White Gritz
attributes.title: White Gritz
attributes.description:
Located in the mountains of northeast Georgia, Barkers Creek Mill has been providing the local community with milling services since the mid 1800s.  The current mill was built in 1944 at the site of an older mill that served the community since the first white settlers came into the area in the late 1820s.  We produce whole wheat flour from hard winter wheat, buckwheat flour comes from Pennsylvania grown buckwheat, and our corn for grits and meal is locally grown both hybrid yellow and a non-hybrid white corn that is a variety unchanged in the local valley since early settlers brought it in.  The white "Keener" corn is a hard, open pollinated flint corn that makes excellent speckled grits and cornmeal.  All our grain products are untreated in any way.  There are no preservatives added and the bran is not sifted away from the germ.
